Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish international, moved to Juventus in 2014 from Real Madrid, with an agreement allowing Real to re-sign him for up to 30 million euros. During his two-year tenure at Juventus, he netted 27 goals, securing two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He participated in both Champions League finals of 2014 and 2015, appearing as a substitute in the 2014 victory and scoring in the 2015 defeat to Barcelona. Prior to his move to Italy, Morata was a promising talent at Real Madrid, making his debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the club. He has since represented Spain at Euro 2016, scoring three times.

In August 2013, Wilson, a 30-year-old midfielder, returned to Championship club Nottingham Forest from Celtic for a fee of £2.5 million. Despite making 51 appearances during his second stint at Forest, he was released in May 2014. Prior to this, Wilson had also played for Preston North End and Notts County, spending four seasons at Forest before his initial departure to Celtic. For the most up-to-date football transfer news, refer to the dedicated page.

British supermarket titan Tesco, the world's third-largest retailer, is planning to sell its struggling US food chain, Fresh & Easy, which has been unprofitable since its 2007 launch. The deal involves transferring approximately 4,000 out of 5,000 Fresh & Easy employees to a new entity, Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm led by billionaire investor Ron Burkle. Yucaipa will receive an initial loan of around £80m from Tesco. The remaining 50 Fresh & Easy stores are expected to be closed. This disposal, valued at £150m for Tesco, includes the loan, which may be repaid. If Yucaipa successfully turns the business around and makes it profitable, Tesco has the option to acquire a stake. This move comes amidst Tesco's own financial challenges, as it reported its first annual profit decline in 20 years in April.

The passage discusses a sports figure who, despite facing racial abuse, has managed to overcome it. Initially, he contemplated representing France but is now concentrating on the 2016 Rio Olympics, aiming for a medal. Additionally, the text provides a link to a special guide on how to engage in martial arts.

In the late 1960s to early 1970s, the ice fields covering Mont Blanc and surrounding European Alps, encompassing approximately 375 sq km, were extensive. By the late 2000s, this area had diminished to around 275 sq km, indicating a significant retreat. This study, presented at the AGU Fall Meeting, is based on research conducted by Marie Gardent from the University of Savoie and her team. They analyzed roughly 600 glaciers across major French Alps massifs like Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, Grande Rousse Arves, and Mont Blanc. Their inventory, the first in four decades, utilized map archives, past satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual inspections to validate satellite data, addressing issues like debris cover and shadows affecting glacier detection.

The initial French Alps glacier inventory, published in the 1980s, noted an overall area of about 375 sq km, which had decreased to nearly 340 sq km by 1985-86. The new survey reveals an average annual loss of approximately 26% over the past 40 years, with the retreat accelerating since the late 1980s. The southern sectors of the French Alps have experienced the most substantial glacial retreat, with the Belledonne Massif seeing almost complete glacier disappearance and the Ecrins Massif showing retreat more than three times faster than the Mont Blanc Massif.

The northern Alps, with their higher mountain elevations and different climatic conditions, have seen less dramatic glacier retreat. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, which descends Mont Blanc, has reduced to about 30 sq km, slightly less than its 1960s/1970s size of 31.5 sq km. This study underscores ongoing efforts to monitor and assess glacier health across the Alpine region, with similar findings reported by Swiss researchers about glacier mass loss in their part of the European Alps.

Scotland, having secured victories in all five qualifiers, hosts Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, with a win potentially securing their place in the major European finals. Scotland's forward, Evans, emphasizes the importance of avoiding another near-miss, having lost in Euro 2013 play-offs and the 2018 World Cup. Iceland, ranked 20th globally, is also unbeaten with four wins from four, and the outcome of this match, along with the return fixture in Reykjavik on September 20, will determine the group's top spot. Evans, aiming for her first major finals, acknowledges the emotional impact of reaching the finals, despite the team's cautious approach. Scotland, as one of the top runners-up, is in a strong position to qualify for the 2022 Women's World Cup in the Netherlands without needing a play-off. Iceland, as the top seed, presents a tough challenge, but Evans believes Scotland has a good chance. The squad, comprising 12 players playing abroad, includes notable achievements like Evans' Bundesliga win with Bayern Munich, where she trained alongside high-profile male players. Evans highlights the benefits of these international experiences, noting the competitive edge and new playing styles they bring to the national team, enhancing Scotland's prospects for a first major finals appearance.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence advocate and blogger from Bath, was arrested in the west of England on Friday. The arrest stemmed from a two-year-old harassment complaint filed by a woman in her 30s from south London. The allegations were made after she visited a local police station. Campbell, who maintains his innocence, was released on bail, with his next court appearance set for mid-September. He denies any serious or threatening conduct, asserting that the alleged harassment pertains to tweets from his Wings Over Scotland blog, all of which remain publicly accessible. Campbell criticizes media coverage, accusing it of spreading "innuendo" to fuel unfounded speculations. He emphasizes that his tweets are not threatening and have not been removed.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) has proposed replacing Skegness' iconic Jolly Fisherman mascot with a more contemporary, animal-friendly image, suggesting a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." The original Jolly Fisherman poster, created in 1908, was commissioned by the Great Northern Railway to promote Skegness as a seaside resort, featuring the slogan "Skegness is so bracing." Despite Peta's concerns that the Jolly Fisherman symbolizes cruel practices like trapping fish and overfishing, Skegness' mayor, Carl Macey, maintains that the character is widely appreciated and does not convey animal cruelty. He believes the Jolly Fisherman represents a happy, friendly figure for the town. Peta's proposal aims to rebrand Skegness as a progressive holiday destination that does not celebrate animal mutilation and killing. The mayor has stated that Peta's suggestion will be considered by the council, but he doesn't anticipate significant changes to the beloved mascot.

In a rugby match, Scotland dominated Georgia, leading 24-11 at halftime. Scotland's early try by Tommy Seymour was followed by additional scores from Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg (two), Hamish Watson, and a penalty try. Georgia's scoring came from Vasil Lobzhanidze (two tries), Merab Kvirikashvili (penalty), and a try from a Georgian scrum. Scotland's possession and territory control (91%) significantly contributed to their scoring. Despite Georgia's second-half resurgence, including a try from a successful scrum and a yellow card for Scotland's Moray Low, Scotland maintained their lead, scoring two more tries in the second half. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised the team's strategic approach and Greig Laidlaw's performance in managing the game. The final score was 38-11 in favor of Scotland.

Widnes Vikings secured a 38-26 victory over Castleford Tigers, maintaining their seventh position in the league table. Key tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor contributed to Widnes' 14-6 lead at half-time. Despite a strong second-half push from Castleford, including three tries in quick succession, Widnes held firm. Mellor's decisive try, capitalizing on Castleford's indecision, initially extended Widnes' lead to 26 points. However, Castleford's Larne Patrick, fresh from signing a new deal with Huddersfield, scored a try, making the final stages tense. Castleford, who have lost four consecutive home league matches, suffered their fourth defeat. Widnes' win, despite their recent poor form, moved them above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth, just one point behind. The teams involved were:

Castleford Tigers: Solomona, Monaghan, Crooks, Webster, Flynn, McShane, Gale, Jewitt, Milner, Patrick, Moors, McMeeken, Massey. Replacements: Millington, Springer, Tickle, Cook.

Widnes Vikings: Hanbury, Thompson, Runciman, Bridge, Ah Van, Mellor, Brown, Cahill, White, Buchanan, Whitley, Dean, Leuluai. Replacements: J. Chapelhow, Manuokafoa, Walker, Heremaia.

Referee: J. Smith.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti national, was released from the US detention facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, after a review panel decided he no longer posed a "continuing significant threat" to the U.S. He had been held since 2002, initially arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of ties to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he vehemently denies. Al-Odah had contested his detention in the U.S. Supreme Court. Upon his release, he departed on a Kuwaiti government plane, expressing no anger or bitterness, but rather joy at returning home. The release was a result of the July 2016 Periodic Review Board's decision that his continued detention was unnecessary for U.S. security. However, he must now undergo at least a year of rehabilitation in Kuwait. This marks the first release since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for U.S. Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl. Al-Odah's release reduces the total number of inmates at Guantanamo to 148. The facility, established in January 2002 following the 9/11 attacks, remains a key point of President Obama's pledge to close.

Anzac Day, commemorating the initial significant battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One, was observed with large-scale services and parades across London. Thousands gathered at Hyde Park Corner for an early morning service, with up to 400 participants in a parade preceding the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. King George V first attended a Westminster Abbey service in 1916, marking the first official commemoration in the capital.

The ceremonies, now a significant event for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians, included the singing of the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia. Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer, who laid a wreath, spoke about the spirit of courage and heroism of the Anzac troops during the Gallipoli landings.

The eight-month campaign at Gallipoli, Turkey, was one of the war's bloodiest, aiming to expel the Ottoman Empire from the conflict. The day's events featured prayers by schoolchildren, reflecting on the sacrifices made by ordinary men fighting for various ideals. Veterans' associations, service and ex-service personnel, and their families participated in the parade at the Cenotaph, with crowds lining the streets to watch.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old player, recently rejoined St Mirren for a second stint in July, potentially making his debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. Last season at Dundee, he netted nine goals and has predominantly been a substitute this term. Clarkson, who has represented Scotland twice with one international goal, has amassed nearly 400 senior club appearances, having previously played for Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. He expressed readiness, stating he's been fit throughout the season, maintaining his fitness through U20s games and intense training. St Mirren, currently eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of Alloa, aims to capitalize on this match to boost their position. Clarkson emphasized the importance of winning games to gain confidence and potentially climb the table. For the most recent transfer updates, refer to the club's transfer deals page.

The turkey firm, previously owned by Bernard Matthews, was acquired by food mogul Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. Concerns arose about the new owners' commitment to the existing workers' pension scheme, specifically the Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme, which was closed in 2004. However, Unite, the union representing workers, reported that productive discussions with Boparan's representatives at the Great Witchingham headquarters resulted in assurances that all current agreements, including the alternative pension scheme for Bernard Matthews' members, would be maintained. Unite's regional officer, Steve Harley, stated that Boparan aims to revitalize Bernard Matthews into a profitable business through increased investment, cost savings, and leveraging the current spare capacity for chicken processing, not just turkey production.

At a council scrutiny meeting, concerns about the newly launched chain ferry were discussed. Council leader Dave Stewart announced a free crossing at Cowes from 15 May until 2 July to address the issues and gather feedback. The council has initiated an audit review of the project due to the ferry's troubled start, which includes breakdowns, groundings, and suspensions by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training problems. These incidents have caused damage to vehicles and disrupted local businesses, particularly shopkeeper Angie Booth's Valu-4-U in East Cowes, which has suffered nearly six months of lost trade.

Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the teething problems, noting that electrical issues have been resolved. He also mentioned the council's authorization for the production of ramp extensions to prevent vehicle scraping on the concrete. Regarding compensation for damaged cars and local businesses, Ward stated it's under discussion. He emphasized that groundings were primarily due to seamanship issues, which have since been resolved.

The House of Lords European Union Committee's report, released in response to Brexit negotiations, highlights the potential risks and opportunities for the UK's fishing industry. The report acknowledges that the fishing sector, which contributes only 0.5% of GDP and employs 12,000 people, might be overlooked in broader Brexit talks. It emphasizes that the industry, which heavily relies on exporting to the EU, needs continued market access post-Brexit.

The Lords suggest that the UK might need to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a deal, given the shared nature of many commercial fish stocks. They advocate for retaining key elements of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) post-Brexit, including basing total allowable catches and quotas on scientific advice. The UK will also maintain international obligations to cooperate with neighboring states.

However, the report warns that Brexit could lead to the fragmentation of the CFP into four separate management regimes for England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. It also notes that EU member states might demand more access to UK waters as a condition for maintaining zero-tariff access to the EU market.

Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry view Brexit as a chance to regain control over UK waters and potentially become a significant global fish exporter, similar to Norway. The recent EU agreement on new CFP quotas, which includes significant increases for plaice, haddock, and prawns, is seen by industry representatives as a positive development, signaling potential opportunities for fairer shares and sustainable management.

The government, in response to the report, affirms its aim to secure maximum trading freedom for British companies within the single market while also utilizing Brexit to reassess and improve fisheries management for fair access to quotas, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney, a 69-year-old former teacher, admitted to possessing and permitting the downloading of hundreds of images depicting young boys in partially erotic poses, between April 2004 and February 2014. As a result, he was issued a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and removed from the teaching profession's register by General Teaching Council Scotland following a hearing. Geaney was also ordered to participate in a specialized sex offender program. The court in Dumfries Sheriff Court heard that the images were of young boys in non-sexual poses, but the nature of his actions was deemed to condone and participate in child exploitation. The GTC Scotland panel found his conduct incompatible with being a registered teacher, citing a pattern of behavior over a significant period, and a high likelihood of recurrence. Geaney was deemed unfit to teach and barred from re-registering for two years, without his presence at the hearing.

Firefighters conducted multiple inspections at a Duncan Street site over the past year due to fire safety concerns, with the Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) visiting nine times. The site, operated by Asset and Land Group, was found to be "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws, according to GMFRS. However, following a blaze on 2 March, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's ability to handle waste, citing potential environmental and public safety risks. The EA's decision, based on GMFRS's concerns about the fire's impact on nearby residents, transport, and the environment, will take effect on 7 August unless the company appeals. The cause of the fire remains unidentified. Asset and Land Group, the site's operators, have not responded to requests for comment.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad of Syria addressed the BBC, asserting that Syria is diligently working towards meeting the deadline for eliminating its chemical weapons. However, Syria missed the Wednesday deadline for delivering its entire stockpile. Al-Mekdad reported that two shipments intended for the Syrian coast were attacked, with the second one being targeted by terrorist groups. He emphasized that Syria is engaged in a war and urged the US and other nations to consider this context.

Al-Mekdad strongly criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, calling it "absolutely unacceptable." The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported 246 casualties, including 73 children, in Aleppo over the past five days due to barrel bomb attacks. Activist groups like The Aleppo Media Centre claim 14 deaths in recent barrel bomb strikes on the Masaken Hanano district.

Al-Mekdad defended Syria's actions, stating they are defending against terrorist attacks and never bombarded civilian areas. He accused the US of supporting terrorist elements in Syria. State media denied reports that rebels had taken control of Aleppo's central prison, claiming soldiers and security forces thwarted an attack. However, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and the Aleppo Media Centre assert that rebels, including the Ahrar al-Sham brigade and al-Nusra Front, have seized the prison, holding at least 3,000 detainees.

Syria possesses approximately 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only about 4% - 30 tonnes - reportedly leaving the country so far. US Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel expressed concern over the slow progress and urged Syria to fulfill its commitment. Russia, a key ally of Syria, has set a March 1 deadline for Syria to transfer the remaining chemical weapons to the coast for shipment. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), overseeing the destruction process, acknowledged security concerns as a factor slowing down the operation. Al-Mekdad reiterated Syria's commitment to its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council, pledging to meet all obligations on time.

In a significant cricket series, England secured a decisive victory at Old Trafford, winning by a substantial margin of 405 runs, their second largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. England's total of 589-8 declared in the first innings and 173-1 declared in the second innings set the stage for this dominant performance.

Joe Root, promoted to the number three position, was the standout performer, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. His performance was praised by both captain Alastair Cook and former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott, with the latter calling it "his best Test-match innings." Root, who had previously made poor decisions in the first Test, emphasized his focus on avoiding such errors.

Root's impact was further highlighted by his fielding, where he took four catches in Pakistan's first-innings 198 and claimed a wicket in his only over, contributing to Pakistan's dismissal for 234.

The pitch at Old Trafford, according to commentators, offered minimal assistance to the bowlers, and Pakistan's batting struggled, with their total of 173-1 declared in the second innings being a significant under-par score.

England's coach Trevor Bayliss noted Root's introspection and hard work post his previous poor performances, which led to his improved form.

The series is now tied at 1-1, with Pakistan set to play a two-day tour match against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston on August 3. Despite England's strong showing, former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott expressed confidence in Pakistan's ability to bounce back, describing the series as "very, very tight."

Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledged their shortcomings, stating they could have scored more and expressed hope for a stronger performance in the upcoming matches.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is initiating a review to assess the quality of life and care provided to older individuals residing in residential care facilities across Wales. This involves gathering firsthand accounts from pensioners and their supporters to understand both positive and negative experiences. The commissioner aims to highlight exemplary care while also exposing instances of substandard care. She has been conducting extensive travels throughout Wales to personally observe the positive effects of high-quality care and has received numerous complaints about varying care standards.

The review will evaluate various aspects of residential care, including physical and psychological health, social connections, and the care home environment. Rochira's team will engage with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies to ensure a comprehensive understanding of the issues. The goal is to create recommendations that will guide improvements in residential care services, ensuring older individuals in Wales receive the best possible quality of life.

However, the Care Forum Wales, represented by Mario Kreft, has expressed concern that the advisory panel for this review lacks representation from individuals with direct experience in running, managing, or owning care homes. They believe this omission hinders the potential for collaborative best practice development and full sector involvement in the advisory process.

Former Arbroath midfielder, Sheerin, 39, has been appointed as the new player-manager at Aberdeen, succeeding Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Sheerin, who previously played for multiple Scottish clubs including Arbroath, also had a stint with Östersunds in Sweden, and earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. He returned to coaching after his playing career. In 2011, while managing Arbroath, Sheerin led the team to their first-ever national trophy, securing the Scottish Third Division title and promotion. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, confirmed that manager Derek McInnes selected Sheerin following a thorough selection process. Despite Aberdeen's interest in retaining Sheerin, Arbroath's chairman, John Christison, facilitated the move, acknowledging Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen. Arbroath was relegated to Scottish League Two in 2013-14, finishing bottom of League One.

Swansea City, following Bob Bradley's dismissal, will be managed by Curtis and assistant Paul Williams in the upcoming match against Bournemouth. The club is keen to swiftly appoint a new manager, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement being their top choice. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after a tumultuous period including near-bankruptcy and relegation threats in 2003, is now aiming to avoid relegation. Former player and current assistant manager Curtis, who has witnessed the club's rise, believes the team has lost its distinctive style and identity since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. He attributes this to frequent managerial changes and the loss of key players. Despite this, Curtis asserts that the current squad is capable of staying up, emphasizing the importance of the club's history and the impact of the documentary "Jack to a King" on new signings, reminding them of the club's journey from near-extinction to Premier League status.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, initiated a competitive race to map the human genome, which led to both acclaim and criticism from the scientific community. Despite his assertive nature, his contributions significantly expedited the human genome project. Post-human genome publication, Venter focused on creating synthetic life forms, culminating in the creation of Synthia, a synthetic organism, published in Science in 2010.

Born in 1946, Venter's life took a dramatic turn during his service in Vietnam, where he worked as a naval hospital orderly, witnessing the high cost of life. This experience instilled in him a strong sense of urgency and a commitment to efficiency. He pursued medical training, excelling in research rather than practice.

In the 1980s, Venter was instrumental in the early molecular biology revolution, recognizing the importance of gene decoding. He introduced automated decoding machines to his lab, speeding up the process. His breakthrough came when he shifted focus from the DNA blueprint to RNA, the messenger molecules cells use naturally, enabling rapid generation of gene sequences.

Venter's work, though initially met with skepticism from notable scientists like James Watson, led to his departure from the National Institutes of Health in 1992. He founded The Institute for Genomic Research and, in 1995, became the first to sequence the genome of a free-living organism, Haemophilus influenzae.

In 1998, Venter founded Celera Genomics, aiming to decode the human genome in three years, challenging the public project's 10-year timeline. Both efforts published their results in 2001. Venter's approach, which prioritized commercialization and speed over open data access, was met with controversy and criticism.

Despite this, Venter's financial success from Celera Genomics provided him with substantial resources to establish the J Craig Venter Institute in 2006. This institute led the creation of the world's first synthetic life form, Synthia, through an extensive genetic exploration of marine microbes.

Venter's synthetic life project, while controversial, holds potential for environmental benefits, such as aiding in carbon capture and reducing reliance on fossil fuels. He continues to engage with both scientific and public discourse, leveraging his resources to pursue ambitious projects beyond the traditional scientific realm.

The Sutton Trust report, conducted by Boston Consulting Group, highlights significant disparities in the quality and quantity of apprenticeships in England compared to other European nations, particularly Germany. The study indicates that fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 annual apprenticeships in England are rated at level three (equivalent to A-levels), while Germany, recognized for its robust vocational education system, offers this level to over half of its apprenticeships. The report also reveals that only 61,000 new apprenticeships in England are for young people, contrasting with Germany's 570,000, 90% of which are at A-level equivalence.

The Sutton Trust calls for a substantial expansion of apprenticeships, proposing up to 300,000 new starts annually, with a focus on level three apprenticeships lasting at least three years and some four-year level four courses. It suggests limiting two-year level two courses to no more than 10% of apprenticeships. The report emphasizes the need for a clear, respected vocational route, contrasting England's current patchwork system with Germany's, where 11 young people compete for each apprenticeship.

However, the Association of Colleges warns that creating 300,000 new apprenticeships could be challenging, especially given the existing shortage of places for 16-year-olds. They also advocate for preserving some level two apprenticeships, like those in construction, which are valued by industry. Despite these concerns, the Department for Education acknowledges the need for reform, stating they are already making significant changes to apprenticeships, including increasing minimum duration, enhancing English and maths requirements, and ensuring apprenticeships are jobs. They plan to publish further reform plans soon.

In Nottwil, Switzerland, British cyclist and Paralympic athlete, Sarah Storey, secured a significant victory, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. This triumph places her in a prime position to claim her 17th title in the upcoming Saturday road race. Storey, a 37-year-old, is Britain's most successful female Paralympian with 22 medals, including 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze across six Paralympic Games. Her notable achievements include four gold medals at the 2012 London Paralympics and 21 world titles in both cycling and swimming. Initially, Storey excelled in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before transitioning to cycling in 2005. She is currently aiming for further Paralympic glory at the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Games.

Hereford United, facing severe financial issues, were on the brink of being expelled from the Football Conference due to their £148,000 debt to football creditors. The Conference extended payment deadlines multiple times, including until June 12, but Hereford failed to meet the final deadline on June 10. This led to their expulsion, with Chester City, who had been relegated, reinstated in their place. The Bulls' predicament was exacerbated by low attendance figures, averaging 1,758 in the 2013-14 season, significantly lower than their League Two average of 3,270. Despite a last-day dramatic win keeping Hereford in the Conference Premier, the club's financial troubles, including unpaid wages and tax demands, ultimately led to their expulsion. The club's new owner, London businessman Tommy Agombar, took over last week, but the damage was done, and the Bulls' fate was sealed.

The 30-year-old former Manchester City player, who made his senior England debut in 2009, has earned 61 caps for the national team. He was part of the squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, yet only featured in three minutes during Euro 2016. He expressed his well wishes to the new England manager, Sam Allardyce, and his team, along with the staff and fans, for future success. Milner also holds the England Under-21 record for the most appearances (46), having made his first appearance in 2004. His sole international goal was scored in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his Cambridge home after a prolonged illness. His funeral was private, with a memorial service planned for a later date. Hogwood, celebrated for his contributions to the early-music movement, worked extensively with global orchestras. He established the AAM in 1973, leading it across six continents for nearly three decades. The AAM, under his direction, produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments.

His notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, recognized by BBC Music Magazine as one of the top 20 recordings of all time. Hogwood's musical education included studying keyboard at Cambridge University under esteemed professors. His career began as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields under Sir Neville Marriner, and he was a founding member of the Early Music Consort of London.

Beyond conducting, Hogwood held prestigious academic positions, serving as a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and professor-at-large at Cornell University. He was also the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society.

His colleagues and peers, including Dame Emma Kirkby and Richard Egarr, praised Hogwood's generosity, ambassadorship for historically informed music, and his ability to nurture future leading orchestra musicians. They highlighted his natural academic prowess, genial personality, and commitment to letting the music speak for itself. His passing was deeply mourned, with tributes emphasizing the significant legacy he left behind in the world of early music.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is being protected, was removed from mainstream schooling in June due to his inability to cope. His parents, who had to quit their jobs to care for him, are currently seeking a place at a special school but are facing a significant delay as all local special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area are fully occupied. The family's local special school has recently hired an additional classroom assistant, offering hope for their son's enrollment soon. However, the mother expresses concern that this situation may reflect a broader issue of overcrowded special needs schools, isolating other families in need. The Education Authority, unable to comment on individual cases due to privacy laws, stated they are reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland to ensure closer proximity to children's residences, with improvements expected from 2016.

The Newport Gwent Dragons, a rugby team, are facing a takeover bid from the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU), who view Rodney Parade stadium as a rugby venue. The team currently leases the ground from 2013 until 2023, with priority of fixtures in the Football League if they remain there. Newport Rugby chairman, Foxall, emphasizes the importance of their contract being respected, stating, "That is something that we're expecting to be honoured."

A shareholder vote is scheduled for early May to decide the WRU's takeover. In 2013, Newport secured a 10-year lease after gaining promotion to the Football League from the Conference. Newport RFC chairman, Godfrey, confirms that both Newport Gwent Dragons and Newport Squash Club, also based at Rodney Parade, are protected under their existing agreements.

The WRU's plan to install an artificial surface, which contravenes Football League rules, has been communicated to the team. On the pitch, Newport Rugby is currently two points above League Two relegation with two games left, having won six out of ten matches under caretaker manager Mike Flynn. They can secure survival with a win and a loss by their rivals, Hartlepool.

Foxall, the caretaker manager, warns that relegation back to the National League would be a significant setback for the team, the fans, and the city of Newport, given their recent promotion to the Football League in 2013.

In the past 18 months, Sierra Leone declared itself free from a virus that had claimed nearly 4,000 lives. The speaker, a former RUF rebel, shares his harrowing experiences during the civil war (1991-2002) and subsequent Ebola crisis. At 15, he was kidnapped, trained, and branded with the RUF symbol, living in constant fear of punishment or death. He describes the brutal realities of life under the rebels, including forced violence, drug use, and cannibalistic acts. After escaping to Freetown, he found solace in a project called Lifeline Nehemiah, founded by preacher Richard Cole, who helped him reintegrate society and pursue education.

Post-war, when Ebola struck Sierra Leone in 2014, the speaker, now a changed individual, led efforts to combat the disease. Despite lacking medical training, they established a clinic, focusing on education, providing essential supplies, and collaborating with other agencies to set up an Ebola treatment unit. Their work saved numerous lives, despite initial community resistance and fear. The speaker emphasizes the importance of investing in young people to build a better future, both for Sierra Leone and globally.

A public fundraising campaign, initiated in September, successfully raised funds to prevent approximately 80,000 artworks, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from being auctioned to settle a pottery firm's pension debt. The collection, which includes significant pieces from the Wedgwood Museum's inheritance from Waterford Wedgwood plc's 2009 collapse, will instead be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum. This museum will subsequently loan the items to the Wedgwood Museum. The campaign, led by The Art Fund, concluded its target in just a month, demonstrating a strong community response. Administrator Bob Young expressed satisfaction, crediting the spirit of goodwill and determination during negotiations for the successful outcome. Alison Wedgwood, a descendant of Josiah Wedgwood, emphasized the collection's importance to Staffordshire, warning of potential global dispersal if the funds hadn't been secured. MP Tristram Hunt praised the sale, highlighting the collection's role in shaping Britain's cultural development and national identity.

Dan Groves, a 30-year-old, is reportedly in negotiations to acquire a 20% stake in Billericay Town, a non-league football club currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot. The deal's specifics, particularly the financial details and roles, remain undisclosed. If the transaction goes through, Wright is expected to become a club director. Billericay's recent acquisition by wealthy investor Glenn Tamplin, who has pledged to invest £10,000 weekly, has set the stage for this potential takeover. Additionally, the club recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, in March.

In a match between Blackpool and Colchester United, Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute through a goal by Jamille Matt, following a precise chip from Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized shortly after from a corner, with Kurtis Guthrie scoring from close range amidst a goalmouth scramble. Despite Blackpool's chances to secure a win, including a missed header by Tom Aldred in the 75th minute, and a blocked shot by Colin Daniel, the game remained tied. Colchester's George Elokobi and Kane Vincent-Young had opportunities to reclaim the lead, but both missed. Blackpool's Tom Aldred headed wide from eight yards. The second half saw Blackpool's Jim McAlister injured and substituted, with Eddie Nolan replacing him. Colchester's Sean Murray was sent off in injury time for a violent tackle on Jim McAlister, leaving them with 10 men. Blackpool's Colin Daniel was also shown a yellow card. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

The Fawley power station, commissioned in 1971 and located on the western shore of Southampton Water, was an oil-fired facility capable of powering one million homes. Its iconic 198-meter-high chimney, once a prominent feature, is now set to be transformed into a key attraction in a new "merchant city" development. This project, led by Fawley Waterside, aims to revitalize the 300-acre site, which includes a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The proposed design is a petal-shaped glass structure, envisioned to be the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. The development, valued at approximately £1 billion, is expected to commence construction in 2018 following an application for outline planning permission later that year. Aldred Drummond, from Fawley Waterside, emphasized the potential of repurposing the chimney as a significant, cost-effective element of the new project, likening it to the i360 in Brighton or the Spinnaker Tower in Portsmouth.

Summary:

At the Hong Kong championships, 23-year-old British cyclist, Latham, secured GB's second medal, claiming bronze in the men's scratch race. He outpaced Adrian Teklinski of Poland (gold) and Lucass Liss of Germany (silver) after a strong final sprint. In the men's team pursuit, Britain finished 4th, while Italy took bronze. Latham's performance was praised by Olympic gold medallists Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy for his strategic timing and powerful final push.

Elinor Barker, a World Championship veteran, joined the team for the quartet event, but the young squad (Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd, and Ellie Dickinson) failed to qualify for the medal round. Barker expressed optimism about their progress, noting the high level of competition and potential for future improvement.

Katy Marchant, a double Olympic gold medallist, was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint. Despite her disappointment, she remains focused on upcoming events, including the 500m time-trial and keirin at the upcoming World Championships.

Elinor Barker, who recently returned from Rio 2016, emphasized the team's youthful potential, with an average age of 19, and their readiness for future competitions, particularly the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.

Ross Kemp, who last portrayed Grant Mitchell in 2006, is set to make a brief return to the BBC soap opera "EastEnders" for Barbara Windsor's (Dame Barbara) final episodes. Kemp's character, Grant Mitchell, a significant figure in the show's 30-year history, will reunite with his brother Phil (played by Steve McFadden) to bid farewell to their mother, Peggy Mitchell, who was diagnosed with cancer. Peggy's character was killed off in emotional scenes planned for the spring, following her surprise reappearance in 2010. Kemp expressed enthusiasm about the reunion, emphasizing the significance of these episodes as "classic EastEnders." The Mitchell brothers' confrontation over their mother's impending death is anticipated to highlight the actors' exceptional performances.

Summary:
- Sadio Mane scored two goals in quick succession, contributing to Tottenham's (Spurs) 2-0 defeat at Anfield, which disappointed their second-place standing in the Premier League.
- Manager Mauricio Pochettino criticized his team's lackluster start, stating it's challenging to compete for the league if they display such lack of desire for victory.
- Chelsea, leading the table, can widen their gap if they win against Burnley on Sunday, a situation Pochettino views as problematic for Spurs.
- Spurs have struggled on the road since September 24, with only two victories in 17 away matches against top-six teams, including defeats at Chelsea and Manchester United, and draws against Arsenal and Manchester City.
- Pochettino highlighted the team's inability to maintain their strong defensive record away from home, emphasizing the need for improvement, especially when facing top-tier opponents.
- Former player Danny Murphy, commenting on Match of the Day, expressed shock at Spurs' performance, noting their usual home-ground prowess contrasted starkly with their away-game inadequacy, suggesting they should stick with their successful three-man defense against top teams.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in Nigeria's recent governorship elections, winning 19 out of 28 governorship seats declared. This marks the most substantial defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP, which lost the presidential election last month, also suffered its first defeat in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, and lost control of Adamawa, a state severely impacted by Boko Haram's insurgency. Despite this, the PDP managed to retain Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, and won eight governorships predominantly in the south-east. The remaining results, particularly in Taraba and Imo, are still pending.

APC's triumph has solidified its position as a dominant force, pushing the PDP to a regional party status. The APC gained stronghold in most northern states and the commercial hub, Lagos, in the south-west, but failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari due to potential disruptions in oil production.

The elections, though marred by violence in parts of the country, were generally more peaceful than in previous years, indicating a maturing democracy. The Independent National Electoral Commission (Inec) reported 66 violent incidents at polling stations, mostly in southern states.

Buhari, the APC's presidential candidate, will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP, after 16 years in power, faces a period of introspection and rebuilding under a new leadership, having been hit by defections of governors and MPs, and accusations of corruption and inadequate response to the north-east insurgency.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, HebCelt, scheduled from 19 to 22 July in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, introduces an augmented reality (AR) feature through a dedicated app. This app enables visitors to access online content linked to physical items like signs and posters across the festival site. The digital material includes videos and band interviews, available for viewing on smartphones and tablets. Notable acts for this year's festival are The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan highlights that this AR experience enhances the festival's appeal, allowing global audiences to engage with the event, access real-time information, interviews, and even purchase tickets, while experiencing the festival's distinct atmosphere remotely.

Birmingham's Park View and Nansen Primary schools, both rated inadequate by Ofsted, face termination of their funding agreements. The Park View Educational Trust may lose control of these schools. Similarly, Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, have been warned their funding could be cut if issues aren't resolved.

Head teachers from these schools, particularly those at Trojan Horse-implicated institutions, have reported parental interference and attempts to undermine their authority during Ofsted inspections. One head teacher felt isolated and questioned her own competence, only realizing later that she was part of a broader issue.

The Ofsted reports, published in response to the Trojan Horse scandal, detail concerns about inadequate extremism prevention measures, including the use of unvetted external speakers and Islamic-themed assemblies featuring extremist guests.

Lord Nash, the education minister, has sent termination notices to Park View and Nansen Primary's trusts, citing deep concerns over their management and failure to promote pupils' spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development. He outlined specific actions, including ending discriminatory practices and improving the curriculum, for the trusts to address these issues by July 4.

Oldknow Academy Trust and Golden Hillock School have also received similar termination notices, with demands for rectifying "less favorable" treatment of non-Muslims, ending segregation, and creating a more balanced curriculum.

Head teachers and staff at Saltley School, the only local authority school in special measures, are working to improve their Ofsted rating through a partnership with other schools. Despite criticism from parents and head teachers about perceived bias in Ofsted's reports, the focus remains on rectifying issues and improving educational standards.

Vincent Barker, referred to as Vinnie, passed away in July 2012, five months post a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The case is currently being heard at Ipswich Crown Court, where eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, is accused of gross negligence manslaughter. The prosecution asserts that Rose's failure to identify Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the test and subsequently refer him for further examination was a critical error, leading to his brain fluid build-up and subsequent fatal condition. The prosecution argues that Rose's conduct fell significantly below the expected standard of an optometrist, making it "criminal" and potentially preventable. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was convicted of coercing a woman into having sexual encounters with a man he arranged through an adult website, from September 2013 to September 2014. He also sent a sexually explicit message to the victim's sister on Christmas Day, 2014. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and sentenced to a higher court for a more severe punishment due to the nature of his crimes. He was found guilty of blackmailing the woman, causing her sister and father to view sexual images, and behaving threateningly or abusively. The woman testified feeling "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg. The judge, Lady Wolffe, emphasized the need for a sentence reflecting society's strong condemnation of such actions. Weatherhogg, a first offender, was deemed to pose a moderate risk of re-offending. The defense acknowledged the shock of Weatherhogg being remanded before sentencing.

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5, with Stuart Thompson contributing 56, Gary Wilson adding 41, and captain William Porterfield scoring 39. However, Ireland fell short due to Afghanistan's strong batting performance, led by Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. Afghanistan reached 171-4 with two overs remaining. Ireland's innings was marred by early wicket losses, including Paul Stirling's duck, and they struggled to add more runs. Amir Hamza (2-23) was the best bowler for Afghanistan. Ireland's captain, Porterfield, acknowledged the team's shortfall, noting they could have aimed for a higher score. Additionally, the loss of paceman Boyd Rankin, due to a back injury, is a significant setback for the Irish team, with his return expected for upcoming ODI matches against Afghanistan starting on 15 March.

FC Barcelona, the Spanish champions, asserts they haven't violated any rules regarding the transfer of Neymar, who joined the club for £48.6m (57m euros) from Santos in the summer. The total cost, including signing-on fee, wages, agents' fees, and a recent tax payment, amounts to £106.8m (135.5m euros). Neymar's parents received £34m from this deal. Barcelona's president, Sandro Rosell, resigned amid allegations of misappropriating funds, which he denies. A judge in Spain has found enough evidence to continue investigating the transfer's fiscal aspects. Barcelona has made a voluntary tax declaration of 13.55m euros to address potential divergent interpretations of their tax obligations. Despite this, the club maintains their original tax payment was in accordance with their fiscal duties. Neymar, since joining, has scored 10 goals in 25 appearances (7 league, 3 Champions League).

British Metropolitan Police officers, dispatched to Thailand to collaborate with local authorities, have concluded their investigation into the murders of Hannah Witheridge, 23, and David Miller, 24, who were found dead on Koh Tao beach on 15 September. The suspects are Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, two 21-year-old Burmese migrant workers. They are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty if convicted. Despite initial reports suggesting they withdrew their confessions, Thai police maintain these have not been withdrawn. The suspects allegedly confessed to the crimes, with DNA evidence linking Win Zaw Htun to Hannah Witheridge. Post-mortem examinations revealed Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Witheridge's death was due to head injuries. The UK Foreign Office raised concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding the verification of DNA samples and allegations of suspect mistreatment, which led to a diplomatic summons to the Thai charge d'affaires. The UK police team will now return to the UK to compile their report and inform the families of the victims about their findings.

Scotland's women's national football team, led by 24-year-old Bayern Munich forward Lisa Evans, has secured all five qualifiers so far and is aiming to clinch their place in the 2019 Women's World Cup by defeating Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday. Evans, who has been aiming for this since joining the squad, emphasizes the importance of avoiding another near-miss, having previously lost in Euro 2013 play-offs and the 2018 World Cup. Iceland, ranked 20th globally, is also unbeaten with four wins from four, making the upcoming match crucial for determining the group's top spot. The best six runners-up automatically qualify for the World Cup, placing Scotland in a strong position. Evans highlights the emotional significance of reaching the finals, despite maintaining a step-by-step approach.

The Scottish squad, currently comprising 12 players playing abroad, includes five in the German Bundesliga, four in Sweden, and two in the U.S. National Women's Soccer League. Recently, Evans won the women's Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, training alongside high-profile male players like Franck Ribery and Arjen Robben. She believes the exposure to top-tier leagues globally, particularly in Germany, enhances the team's competitiveness and overall quality. Evans notes that while the Scottish league is improving, the international experience of these players adds a unique dimension to the national team, contributing to their readiness for a first major finals appearance.

The passage discusses a security measure implemented by Apple to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud accounts, following a recent incident where third-party software was used to steal and post intimate photos of celebrities. This new security feature, known as two-step verification, introduces an additional authentication step after entering username and password on a new device. This step requires users to input a four-digit code sent via text or Apple's Find My iPhone app, or use a 14-character recovery key. If the code isn't entered, access to iCloud, iTunes, iBooks, or App Store is denied.

Despite Apple previously offering this feature, it hadn't been enforced when using iCloud backup service. This oversight allowed hackers to download full device backups even with two-step authentication enabled, using tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Elcomsoft's owner, Vladimir Katalov, acknowledged his software was used in the recent hacks but now believes Apple's updated system is secure, with no known workaround.

Apple's new security enhancement includes email notifications for every iCloud backup start, regardless of two-factor authentication status. However, security experts have mixed opinions. While some, like Prof Alan Woodward from the University of Surrey, advocate for making two-factor authentication the default setting across platforms, including Apple, Microsoft, and Google, to combat vulnerabilities of single-step verification. They argue that users should have the option to opt-out if they prefer.

Apple, in response to the incident, plans to encourage more users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords. CEO Tim Cook emphasized the importance of raising user awareness about cybersecurity, acknowledging that while engineering solutions are crucial, public education is equally vital in preventing such breaches.

During the 2014 European elections, UKIP, the winning party, allocated £2,956,737 for their campaign, equating to 68p per vote (out of 4,376,635 votes). The Conservatives, who came second, spent £2,980,815, or 79p per vote (from 2,980,815 votes). Labour, in third place, spent £1,027,339, or 26p per vote (from 1,255,573 votes). The Liberal Democrats, who lost 11 of their 12 MEPs, spent £1,580,575, or £1.45 per vote (from 1,255,573 votes). The Green Party, fourth, spent £534,249, or 43p per vote (from 1,255,573 votes). The Scottish National Party (SNP) contributed £267,372. The total expenditure by the top six parties was £9,347,087. Notably, all parties except Labour increased their campaign spending compared to the 2009 elections.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back with experience at Aldershot, Exeter, and Italian clubs, has terminated his contract with Barrow on mutual terms to join their National League rivals. He might face his former club, Barrow, on 18 February. Meanwhile, 21-year-old striker Keating, previously with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, has been recommended by former Port Vale manager Micky Adams to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson. Keating's move is pending international clearance. Nicholson praised Anderson for his leadership qualities, despite his limited game time, while describing Keating as young and eager to prove himself. The Gulls, currently four points above the relegation zone, have won just one of their last six matches.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, who had previously won prestigious races including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Despite showing no prior signs of post-race ataxia, a condition causing overheating and wobbling, he had a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, as confirmed by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA). This incident, though rare, occurred in a horse with no known underlying health issues. Tony Welsh, acting chief veterinary officer for the BHA, emphasized the rarity of such events and the commitment to investigate potential causes and preventive measures. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described Many Clouds as "the horse of a lifetime," highlighting his significant achievements. The BBC correspondent Cornelius Lysaght noted that Many Clouds had previously been treated for overheating after his Grand National success, but no direct link to his death was established in this report.

In the Scottish Parliament, veteran politicians Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and Tricia Marwick are stepping down ahead of the 5 May election. During their farewell speeches:

- Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, expressed visible emotion, particularly after Salmond and McNeil's addresses.
- Alex Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, delivered a valedictory speech emphasizing Scotland's unity and diversity, stating that the country and parliament are on a journey towards greater responsibility in governance. He acknowledged the Scotland Bill's positive impact but criticized it for not fully fulfilling pre-referendum pledges. Salmond also joked about the competition from the Cheltenham racecourse, expressing well-wishes for all election candidates.
- Duncan McNeil, a Labour MSP, delivered a powerful final speech, warning Holyrood about the need for improved accountability, scrutiny, and opposition, drawing parallels with Westminster's committee system. He expressed regret at having to learn from Westminster's practices.
- Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also announced her departure, humorously mentioning her future interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

All three MSPs praised each other's service to the parliament and Scotland, highlighting their significant contributions.

In the upcoming Disney live-action adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast," set for release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017, Emma Watson will portray Belle, the protagonist. The film's Beast is to be played by Downton Abbey's Dan Stevens. Kevin Kline will essay Maurice, Belle's father, while Harry Potter's Oscar-winner, Emma Thompson, is confirmed for an unspecified role. Dame Angela Lansbury, who voiced Mrs Potts in the 1991 animated version, will reprise her character in this live-action adaptation. Kevin Kline also takes on Maurice, the father of Belle. Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will be Gaston. Josh Gad, known for voicing Olaf in "Frozen," will portray LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. Bill Condon, director of "Dreamgirls" and the last two "Twilight" films, will helm the project, with filming commencing at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to disclose its stance on potential charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster at a confidential gathering with victims' families in Warrington, scheduled for 11:00 BST. Ninety-six football fans perished in this tragedy. Last year, new inquests confirmed the fans were unlawfully killed. The CPS is currently reviewing evidence from 23 suspects, with 15 pertaining to Operation Resolve, an investigation into the disaster's causes, and the remaining eight concerning the conduct of South Yorkshire and West Midlands Police following the incident. Sue Hemming, head of the CPS's special crime and counter-terrorism division, will inform the families of the decisions. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died, expressed hope that this is the final step towards justice, emphasizing the families' determination for accountability, despite acknowledging it will be a prolonged process.

Chelmsford Prison has reported a surge in contraband incidents, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, which are reportedly being thrown over the prison wall. A former inmate claims the jail is "notorious" for such activities, even suggesting the use of drones for delivering contraband directly to prison windows. However, the Ministry of Justice denies the use of drones, stating there's no evidence of this happening at Chelmsford. Despite these claims, the Ministry acknowledges the staff's efforts to prevent contraband entry and emphasizes the need for further measures. The Justice Secretary has initiated a review to explore additional tools for prisons to combat this issue, as laws now allow for up to two years' imprisonment for those caught smuggling packages over prison walls. Residents living near the prison have reported witnessing packages being thrown over the wall frequently, with one woman mentioning four incidents in two weeks. The prison has invited the community to a meeting to discuss appropriate actions if contraband is thrown over.

Brian Wright, 55, from Kempston, is on trial at Luton Crown Court for causing serious injury by dangerous driving, specifically for a collision with Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a 20-year lollipop lady, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and doesn't recall if the traffic lights were red or green. Despite his assertion, his VW Golf failed to stop at a red light, hitting Mrs. Blackburn who was directing traffic. She sustained severe head injuries and is now in residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse, acknowledging Mrs. Blackburn's significant role in the community and the profound impact of his actions on her and her family. The incident occurred when Mrs. Blackburn was on duty, having stopped traffic to let a woman and her six-year-old daughter cross the road. The prosecution stated that the sun was 10 minutes from setting, potentially causing significant glare. The trial is ongoing.

Scottish middle-distance runner, Jemma Reekie (referred to as 'Muir' in the passage), will miss the 2022 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her commitment to veterinary medicine studies. Muir, 24, recently finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m events at the World Athletics Championships. Her university exams, scheduled for May, conflict with the Commonwealth Games' April timing. Despite her absence, Muir expresses enthusiasm for the Scottish team's performance, emphasizing her dedication to completing her degree. She also hints at potential participation in the World Indoor Championships in March, stating, "These next few months are going to be very full on with my studies." Muir's personal best in the 5,000m, achieved at 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in a recent race, reflects her competitive form. She remains optimistic about future Olympic prospects, though specific events are yet to be determined.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man from County Kildare, went missing on Christmas night in 2000 while walking home from a party. His disappearance led to a search in Chapelizod, Dublin, a three-acre woodland area near the R112 and the River Liffey. This search, initiated in early December 2022, involves excavations and is projected to last several weeks. In April, enhanced CCTV footage from the night of his disappearance was released, showing Deely conversing with a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street. The man is believed to have been with Deely shortly after the party, possibly to retrieve an umbrella. Gardaí (Irish police) have not yet identified this individual and are urging him to come forward. A team of six detectives began reviewing Deely's case earlier this year.

Juan Martin Del Potro, ranked 165th, secured a 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 victory over Switzerland's Stan Wawrinka in a grueling Wimbledon match. Despite missing over two years due to injuries, Del Potro, a former world number four, is now playing in his first Grand Slam since the Australian Open in 2014. He overcame an early setback, winning the second set, and then fought back to win the third set in a tie-break before clinching the fourth set. Del Potro, who reached the Wimbledon semi-finals in 2013, expressed his joy and relief, stating he's enjoying playing tennis again after a tough period.

In the same draw, Britain's Andy Murray will face either France's Lucas Pouille or American Donald Young next. Nick Kyrgios, ranked 15th, also advanced to the third round after a rain-affected, five-set victory over Germany's Dustin Brown, 6-7 (3-7), 6-1, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4. Kyrgios will next play Feliciano Lopez, with the winner progressing to face Murray or John Millman in the last 16. Other notable wins included 10th seed Tomas Berdych and 12th seed Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, both securing straightforward victories.

Tunisia and Morocco, both African nations, faced significant challenges in qualifying for the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was initially threatened with expulsion due to complaints lodged against CAF (Confederation of African Football) during the 2017 Nations Cup. However, after apologizing, Tunisia secured their participation.

Morocco, on the other hand, was initially banned from the 2017 qualifiers due to their refusal to host the 2015 Nations Cup, citing Ebola concerns. This ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), reducing their fine from $1m to $50,000. Equatorial Guinea stepped in to host the 2015 tournament, despite having only 64 days to prepare.

Tunisia's troubles escalated when they were leading 1-0 against Equatorial Guinea in the quarter-finals but were awarded a controversial penalty, leading to a 2-1 loss in extra time. This incident prompted Tunisia to write a strongly worded letter to CAF, accusing the organization of poor referee selection rather than corruption. This led to a demand for an apology by CAF, which Tunisia responded to, and a subsequent meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou in Senegal, resolving their dispute.

Both nations are now set to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup. Tunisia, in Group A, will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, while Morocco, in Group F, will compete against Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome. Should Tunisia advance, they would secure their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance, a record.

McLaren, a renowned Formula 1 team with an impressive history of 182 wins, 12 world championships, and 8 constructors' titles, finds itself in a significant slump, currently occupying the fourth row of the grid. This decline began in 2013 due to issues with their chassis design, despite retaining a strong Honda power-unit. Historically, McLaren has experienced cycles of triumph and decline, with notable periods of dominance in the 1980s (15 out of 16 races with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost) and 1998-99 (Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines). Their last constructors' title was in 1998.

The team's current struggles are attributed to the Honda engine problems, a stark contrast to their successful partnership with Honda in the past. Post-1999, McLaren has seen intermittent success, but the wins have dried up. Their last win was in 2012, when Lewis Hamilton and Jenson Button secured seven victories together.

Ron Dennis, who has been at the helm since 2009, is optimistic about a return to form. He believes McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance in F1 and win championships again. Fernando Alonso, a two-time world champion, returned to McLaren in 2015, partly due to his belief in the Honda partnership as his best chance to secure a third title. Despite the current setbacks, Dennis and his team maintain that the current car is among the best and that Honda's engine will improve next year, signaling a potential resurgence.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, at 06:00 BST. Police discovered patrons still present at the bar, with till receipts indicating alcohol was served until 04:49 BST, violating licensing hours. Limavady Magistrates Court subsequently ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both residing at Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. O'Neill, the license holder, was found to have an "appalling record" and was fined £3,000. Thomas was fined £1,000. The court acknowledged the premises' improper management and non-adherence to Dungiven's licensing laws.

Stephen Curry surpassed his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points in a game against the Portland Trail Blazers. This record, previously set two years ago, was 272. Curry achieved this by hitting eight 3-pointers before halftime and a total of eight overall, aiding the Golden State Warriors' comeback from a 13-point deficit. Alongside Klay Thompson, known as the "Splash Brothers," Curry's performance helped the Warriors secure a 116-105 victory. Curry also contributed nine assists.

In another game, the Chicago Bulls, led by Pau Gasol's 16 points and 15 rebounds, overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78. The Bulls' second-half surge, a 39-8 run, was crucial, as the Heat missed their first 12 shots after halftime and were outscored 57-27 in the second half. Pau Gasol's strong performance, along with 14 points from Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson, secured the win for the Bulls, who moved into the third spot in the Eastern Conference.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic encountered an unexpected surprise at Melwood training ground when Dutch free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen, a YouTube sensation, arrived. Initially, the players were under the impression that van Velzen was a competition winner who had won the chance to meet the Anfield stars and receive a dead-ball coaching session. However, it soon became evident that he was a skilled footballer himself, showcasing his impressive free-kick abilities. Balotelli and Borini were particularly impressed, with Balotelli even executing a perfect strike into the top corner. Van Velzen, known for his videos showcasing his free-kick prowess, reveled in the experience, finding satisfaction in outshining the Liverpool stars. He also had a personal moment with Balotelli, revealing the latter's famous 2011 Manchester City shirt, which featured the slogan "I'm not a witch, I'm a god."

The passage discusses the impact of oophorectomy (removal of ovaries) on reducing breast cancer mortality for women carrying the BRCA1 gene, similar to Hollywood star Angelina Jolie. Jolie, 39, had this procedure (known as an oophorectomy) in March, following a double mastectomy due to her BRCA1 gene mutation, which significantly increases the risk of breast and ovarian cancer.

A Canadian study analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with mutated BRCA1 or BRC2 genes. The findings indicate that oophorectomy, performed an average of six years post-diagnosis, reduced breast cancer deaths by 62% in BRCA1 mutation carriers. This protective effect was immediate and lasted for 15 years. However, it did not apply to BRC2 mutation carriers.

The study found a 65% reduction in all-cause deaths among oophorectomy recipients. For BRCA1 carriers who had their ovaries removed within two years of diagnosis, the reduction in death was 73%. The 20-year survival rate for the entire group was 77.4%.

Dr. Steven Narod from the Women's College Research Institute in Toronto advocated for further follow-up studies on women who undergo oophorectomy as part of their initial treatment, especially those who had the surgery within a year of breast cancer diagnosis. Journal editor Dr. Mary Disis emphasized the compelling results, suggesting that oophorectomy should be considered as part of treatment discussions for early-stage BRC1 mutation carriers with breast cancer.

Women with a significant family history of breast cancer, particularly those with a 50-80% lifetime risk due to BRC1 or BRC2 gene mutations, may benefit from genetic testing. The BRC1 mutation is more prevalent in the Ashkenazi Jewish population, affecting about 2.3% of these women. The study also highlighted that oophorectomy provides survival benefits, especially for those with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer, an aggressive form often resistant to drug treatment.

Angelina Jolie, who has six children, stated that having her ovaries removed did not diminish her sense of femininity, emphasizing her personal choice and grounding in her family's well-being.

On Easter Sunday, a married couple, Derek Loewe, 38, and Tina Loewe, 33, were fatally struck by an Amtrak train (Carolinian, heading from Charlotte to New York City) in Durham, North Carolina, around 10 am. The incident occurred on Norfolk-Southern property. Despite the tragedy, none of the 166 passengers on the train were injured. A passenger who met the couple while they were collecting scrap metal reported they might have been homeless, living in a camp. The train, delayed for nearly three hours due to the incident, resumed its journey to Raleigh, which is approximately 25 miles northwest of Durham. The train's usual journey from Charlotte to New York City takes about 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years, providing crucial information that led to the downfall of significant drug figures like Carlos Lehder Rivera and Manuel Noriega. Toro fled Colombia in the 1980s due to a threat on his life and sought refuge in the U.S., where he began his DEA work. Despite his invaluable contributions, he was never promised U.S. citizenship, a fact he was led to believe would be his reward. Now, facing retirement due to health issues, Toro is being deported, as the DEA has reneged on its promise. Toro, who has lived in the U.S. illegally for years, fears for his life upon returning to Colombia. His handler, DEA agent Mike McManus, has publicly expressed dismay at the situation, calling it "government bureaucracy at its worst." Toro is currently in a legal limbo, unable to secure a green card, passport, or social security benefits, and is considering hiding if necessary.

The U.S. Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for allegedly exploiting the newly introduced '.sucks'domain names to extort substantial fees from celebrities and companies aiming to safeguard their reputations. Notable celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift have reportedly paid to have their names removed from these domains, which include major brand names such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, Yahoo, and Telus Mobility. Vox Populi began accepting registrations for these domains on March 30, targeting trademark holders and celebrities before opening them to the public. The company charges around $2,499 annually for these domains, with resellers often selling them for approximately $2,000. ICANN, after initial approval, is now reviewing the legality of Vox Populi's actions following complaints from an advisory panel, which deems the practice a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory." ICANN has sent letters to the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs, seeking clarification on potential illegalities. If found illegal, ICANN could declare Vox Populi in breach of contract and take further actions to modify the registry's behavior.

A 27-year-old unsolved case from 1988 in Norfolk, England, was resolved when DNA evidence led police to the mother of a stillborn baby boy. The infant's body was discovered in June 1988, floating in a Sainsbury's bag on a pond in Weasenham St Peter. Initially, the cause of death remained undetermined due to a lack of evidence. The mother, who has not been named, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but later confessed to concealing her pregnancy and delivering the stillborn baby herself. She admitted to placing the baby in the pond shortly after its birth. The DNA match from the exhumed leg bone led investigators to her, and she was identified as a relative of one of the parents. The woman explained her actions, stating she had given birth alone and disposed of the baby in the pond. The baby, named Peter after the local church, was reburied in June 2020, 26 years after his discovery, with a new headstone. The case was reviewed periodically, and the latest DNA technology played a crucial role in solving it. The mother, now on bail, faces potential charges for failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. The community, including a support group for stillbirth parents, contributed to the baby's reburial, emphasizing his memory and the hope for support for those in similar situations.

Michael Young, a 56-year-old former soldier and taxi driver from Bath, Somerset, was ordered by a judge to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from a moving taxi in 2010. The incident occurred when Hicks, then 23, was returning home with his girlfriend from a night out. Young, mistakenly believing Hicks intended to "do a runner" and not pay the fare, drove him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson. Despite Hicks' objections, Young continued driving for nearly a mile, leading to Hicks' escape. Hicks jumped from the moving vehicle at over 20mph, sustaining life-altering brain injuries, epilepsy, and requiring round-the-clock care from his mother.

The High Court, presided by Mr. Justice Edis, ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The exact compensation amount, estimated to be around 50% of what the family had sought (hundreds of thousands of pounds), is yet to be determined.
